JavaScript ES6

var, let, & const

Difference between var and let

In JavaScript vars are easily overwritten. ES6 introduced a more secure variable keyword let, which can only be declared once per variable. It prevents from important variables being overwritten.

Comparing scopes of the var and let keywords

Let behaves just like var, but has some exclusive functions:

Within a block, statement or expression, a let variable is limited to that specific location. 

var numArray = [];
for (let i = 0; i < 3; i++) { // `i` is defined as `0` and will stay exclusive to the `for loop` scope.
    numArray.push(i);
}

console.log(i) //`i` is undefined because it is only within the scope of the `for loop`.

Declaring a read only var with const

Variables declared with const are read only, meaning that they are constant variables and cannot be reassigned.

Note: It's common to use UPPERCASE for variable indentifiers for imutable values and lowerCase camelCase for mutable values such as objects and arrays.

Mutate an array declared with const

Some developers always us const unless they are certain that they will have to change the variable.

An array value declared and assigned with const cannot be reassigned as a whole, but its content can be altered individually.

const S = [5, 6, 7];
S = [1, 2, 3]; // !Will result in an error!
S[2] = 45; // Works like normal.

Prevent object mutation →Object.freeze()

Using the built-in function Object.freeze() ensures that data of certain objects doesn't change no matter what.

function freezeObj() {
    'use strict'
    const MATH_CONSTANTS = {
        PI: 3.14
    };

    Object.freeze(MATH_CONSTANTS);

    try {
        MATH_CONSTANTS.PI = 99;
    } catch (ex) {
        console.log(ex);
    }
    return MATH_CONSTANTS.PI
}
const PI = freezeObj();

Object.freeze will perform a shallow freeze on an object, but will not protect deep properties from being mutated.

Arrow Functions

Use arrow function to write a concise anonymous function

In JavaScript functions often don't have to be named, especially when being passed as arguments in other functions.

Using inline functions instead, we don't need to name these one-time-use functions.

// Standard notation:
const myFunc = function() {
    const myVar = 'value';
    return myVar; // Returns the `myVar` variable
}

The same function can be written more concise using ES6, shortening function() to simply () =>

// `ES6` simplified notation:
const myFunc = () => {
    const myVar = 'value';
    return myVar;
}

When there's no body function and only a return value, arrow function syntax allows you to omit the keyword return as well as the brackets surrounding the code, simplifying the code even further.

const myFunc = () => 'value';
// `myFunc` will automatically return `'value'`.

Arrow functions with parameters

Parameters and modifiers

const doubler = (item) => item * 2;
// An arrow function with parameters and value modifications.

Omitting the parenthesis on a single parameter

const tripler = item => item * 3;
// With single parameters the parenthesis may be omitted.

Multiple parameters

const multiplier = (item, factor) => item * factor;
// An arrow function with multiple parameters.

Set default parameters for functions →creates more flexible functions

Default function parameters kick in when an argument is not specified:

// Creating a function with a default function parameter for `name`:
const greeting = (name = "anonymous user") => "Hello" + name;

// Calling `greeting` with a defined parameter:
console.log(greeting("John"));
//returns: Hello John

// Calling `greetings` without a parameter:
console.log(greeting());
//returns: Hello anonymous user

rest parameter & spread operator

Use the ...rest parameter with function parameters

rest parameters allow functions that take a varying number of arguments. These arguments are stored in an array that can be accessed later from within its function.

function howMany(...args) { // `args` can be named anything.
    return "You have passed " + args.length + "arguments.";
}

console.log(howMany(0, 1, 2));
// returns: "You have passed 3 arguments."

console.log(howMany("hello", true, 43, "something"));
// returns: "You have passed 4 arguments."

Use the spread operator to evaluate arrays in place

The spread operator allows for the expansion of arrays and other expressions in place where multiple parameters or elements are expected.

ES5 → apply() to find the highest array value

var array = [6, 89, 3, 45];

var maximus = Math.max.apply(null, array);
//returns: 89

Without the spread operator, the way to find the highest values of array was by Math.max.apply(null, array). This because Math.max cannot handle arrays on its own.

In ES6

const array = [6, 89, 3, 45];

const maximus = Math.max(...array);
// `...array` returns an unpacked array, meaning it spreads the array.

Note: ...array only works as a placeholder, like a function argument or in an array literal. const spread = ...array; is invalid.

Destructuring assignments

Use destructuring assignments to extract values from an object

Introduced in ES6, the destructuring assignment helps neatly assigning values taken directly from an object.

ES5 v. ES6

// Consider the following object `User`...
const user = {name: "Mark", age: 32};

// ES5
const name = user.name //name = "Mark"
const age = user.age //age = 32

//ES6
const { name, age } = user;
console.log(name, age); // returns: "Mark" 32

Using the ES6 method, the name & age variables will be created and assigned the values of their respective values from the user object.

Use destructuring assignments to assign variables from objects

This lets you assign values of objects to new variables. →const {name: userName}.

const HighTemps = {
    yesterday: 75,
    today: 77,
    tomorrow: 80
};

const {today: highToday, tomorrow: highTomorrow} = HighTemps;
// Creates a new variable `highToday` and `highTomorrow`.

Use destructuring assignments to assign variables from nested objects

Consider object user:

const user = {
    johnDoe: {
        age: 34,
        gender: "male"
    }
};

Extracting values

const {johnDoe: {age, gender}} = user;

Extract and assign to variables

const {johnDoe: {age: userAge, gender: userGender}} = user;

Use destructuring assignment to assign variables from array

Consider:

const [a, b] = [1, 2, 3, 4];

The variable a is assigned to the first value (1) and b to the second value (2) of the array.

The value of any index can be reached by using , to reach the desired index:

const [a, b, ,, ,c] = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]; // [a(1), b(2), (3), (4), c(5)]
console.log(a, b, c) // return: 1, 2, 5

Use destructuring assignment with the rest parameter to reasign array elements

const [a, b, ...arr] = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7];

console.log(a, b) // returns: 1, 2
console.log(arr) // returns: 3, 4, 5, 6, 7

Use destructuring assignment to pass an object as a function's parameter

In some cases, you can destructure the object in a function argument itself.

consider:

const profileUpdate = (profileData) => {
    const {name, age} = profileData;
};

// do something with these variables...

The same can be done in place:

const profileUpdate = ({name, age}) => {
    // do something with these variables...
};

Another example

const stat = {
    max: 56.83,
    standard_deviation: 4.24,
    median: 34.45,
    mode: 23.34,
    min: -0.74,
    avg: 34.85
};

const half = ({min, max}) => (min + max) / 2.0;
// returns: 28.0

Template- & Object Literals

Create strings using template literals

Template literals are special types of strings to help create complex strings.

Qualities of a string with template literals:

  • looks like ${a_variable};
  • is wrapped in backticks;
  • is multi-line (doesn't need \n to break lines);
  • does not require + operators;
  • can process operations $(a + b).

Example using template literals

const person = {name: "Zodiac", age: 43};

const greeting = `Hello, my name is ${person.name}!
I am ${person.age} years old.
I was born in ${currentYear - person.age}.`;

Write concise object literal declarations using object property shorthand

consider:

const getMousePosition = (x, y) => ({
    x: x,
    y: y
});

// `getMousePosition` simply returns an object with 2 properties.

Simplified ES6 syntax

const getMousePosition = (x,y) => ({x,y});

also:

const createPerson = (name, age) => {
    return {name, age};
};
createPerson("Nick", 18); // name: "Nick" age: 18;

Write concise declarative functions

In ES5 methods within an object are written like so:

const person = {
    name: "Taylor",

    sayHello: function() {
        return `Hello, my name is ${this.name}.`;
    }
};

In ES6 you can leave out the :colon and function keyword.

const person = {
    name: "Taylor",
    sayHello() {retrn `Hello I'm ${this.name}.`;}
};

Use the class syntax to define a constructor function

ES6 introduced the class keyword: a syntax that isn't exactly a complete class system as in Java, Ruby, or Python, but it adds some handy functionality to ES6.

In ES5 an object is instantiated by defining a constructor function and using the new keyword, like:

var SpaceShuttle = function(targetPlanet) {
    this.targetPlanet = targetPlanet;
}
// A new `SpaceShuttle` object with target: 'Jupiter'...
var zeus = new SpaceShuttle('Jupiter');

in ES6:

class SpaceShuttle {
    constructor(targetPlanet) {
        this.targetPlanet = targetPlanet;
    }
}
// New `SpaceShuttle`...
const zeus = new SpaceShuttle('Jupiter');

Using the class keyword also requires the use of a constructor() keyword, which takes the object parameter as an argument.

Use getters & setters to control access to an object

Getter function

Getters return the values of an object's private variable to the user without directly providing the user access to the variable.

Setter function

Setters modify the value of an object's private variable based on the value passed into the setter function, which can involve calculation or even overwrite previous values.

// Book constructor...
class Book {
    constructor(author) {
        this._author;
    }
    get writer() {
        return this._author;
    }
    set writer(updateAuthor) {
        this._author = updateAuthor;
    }
}

// new object from `Book` constructor...
const novel = new Book('Sara B. Tupple');
console.log(novel.writer); // 'Sara B. Tupple'

novel.writer = 'New Author';
console.log(novel.writer); // 'New Author'

Getter & setter functions are important because they hide the internal implementation details.

Note: It is conventional to precede a private function with an _underscore, though it does not carry any function and doesn't make a variable private.

Module scripts, import & export

Create a module script

ES6 introduced a way to easily share code between JavaScript files. It allows any part of the code to be exported and implemented into another file.

a module script:

<script type="module" src="file.js"></script>

Use export to share a codeblock

Imagine a JavaScript file with several functions you want to reuse in other .js-files.

In order to share with other files, you need to export it.

// method 1
export const add = (x,y) => {
    return x + y;
}

// method 2
const add = (x,y) => {
    return x + y;
}

export { add };
export { add, subtract, divide } // multiple

Using import to reuse JavaScript code

Once code is epxorted, this is how you retrieve it into another file:

import { add } from './math_functions.js';

// Multiple modules from single source
import { add, subtract } from './math_functions.js';

Using * to import everything from a file

import * as myMathModule from './math_functions.js';
// myMathModule a variable name

The above creates an object that contains all the exports from 'math_functions.js', allowing you access to the object properties.

Calling functions from imported properties is simply done by calling the object and method, like so:

myMathModule.add(2, 3);
myMathModule.subtract(5, 2);

Create an export fallback with export default

Usually you'll use the export default syntax if only one value is being exported from a file.

It is also used to create a fallback value for a file or module.

// named function
export default function add(x,y) {
    return x + y;
}

// anonymous function
export default function () {
    return x + y;
}

Since export default is used to declare a fallback value for a file or module, you can only have one value be a default export in each module or file.

Additionally, you cannot use export default with var, let, or const.

Import a default export

To import a default export, you need to use a different import syntax:

import add from './math_functions.js';

Note: add is not surrounded by {}. It is simply a variable name for whatever the default export of the math_function.js file is. You can use any other name.

JavaScript promises

Creating a JavaScript promise

A promise in JavaScript say you'll do something, usually asynchronously.

When the task is completed, you will have either fullfilled or broken the promise.

It is a constructor function and uses the new keyword. It takes a function with arguments: resolve & reject to determine the promise outcome.

const myPromise = new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
    // do something
});

Complete a promise with resolve & reject

A promise has 3 states: pending, fullfilled, and completed.

Resolve and reject parameters are used to determine the state of the promise.

Resolve is used when you want the promise to succeed;

Reject is used when you want it to fail.

const myPromise = new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
    if (/*condition*/) {
        resolve("Promise was fulfilled");
    }else{
        reject("Promise was rejected");
    }
});

Handle a fulfilled promise with then

Promises are most useful when you have something that takes an undefined amount of time, like a server request.

With the then keyword you can do something immediately once the promise is resolved, like so: 

myPromise.then(result => {
    // Do something with `results` here...
});

result comes from the arguments given to the resolve method.

Handle a rejected promise with catch

The catch method is used when a promise is rejected, like so:

myPromise.catch(error => {
    // Do something with `error` here...
});

error is the argument passed into the reject method.
